_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: EO Tank and auxiliary equipment and unloading system

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
We at Tate & Lyle-Decatur are strongly committed to employees, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility. It is our policy to implement the appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
Our facility's primary activities encompass the manufacture of corn syrup, dry dextrose, industrial starch, and baking starches. We have two regulated substances at our facility, ethylene oxide and sulfur dioxide. Ethylene oxide is used in starch modification. Sulfur dioxide is utilized in the steeping step of the corn wet milling process.

The storage system for EO is designed to prevent overheating and contamination of EO. Specific additional measures for EO storage passive mitigation include a break tank and a sump in the secondary containment area. Specific measures for EO storage active mitigation include a one-million gallon disposal tank, a packed-column vapor scrubber, improved cooling of ethylene oxide transfer, enhanced process control and detection systems. Nitrogen continues to be utilized for the bulk storage tank, break tank, and railcar blanketing. The capability has been added to use nitrogen for maintenance purging.

PASSIVE MITIGATION
The addition of a BREAK TANK creates a BREAK between the process and the bulk storage tank. Isolating the process from bulk storage will reduce the risk of contaminants getting into bulk storage. Contaminents could lead to unwanted reactions causing temperature rise, pressure rise, or increase in level.

The storage area incorporates a sloped diked area around railcar unloading and bulk storage, draining to a sump. The sump allows reclamation of any spilled materi

al or deluge water.

ACTIVE MITIGATION
The one-million gallon DISPOSAL TANK allows emptying and dilution of the EO in the bulk storage tank and the break tank. The tank is maintained at sufficient levels of water to allow dilution of the EO. There are also provisions to mix caustic with the EO to speed the conversion to ethylene glycol.

Vapor can be generated for maintenance activities requiring tank and/or pipe purging. Vapor can also result from venting of the bulk storage tank in the unlikely event that high pressures and high temperatures occur from contamination of the EO. The PACKED COLUMN vapor scrubber converts EO vapor into glycol liquid which can be safely handled in the facility pre-treatment plant.

The IMPROVED COOLING SYSTEM in the new storage compound maintains the temperature in the storage tank at 50-55 F. The cooling system includes a cooling jacket on the bulk storage tank and a heat exchanger on the transfer system.

PROCESS CONTROLS have been utilized in the past to ensure the continuous monitoring of EO. 
The Ethylene Oxide storage system has many layers of safety to prevent a release of ethylene oxide from the storage tank and associated system. All control interlocks are designed to shut down the system and bring it to a safe state for inspection and troubleshooting. There are EO ambient sensors placed around the new EO storage compound that are continuously monitored by the Central Control personnel. The EO storage tank has a mechanical excess flow valve on its discharge. The system also has an emergency air supply enabling system operation even in the event of a power outage.

Sulfur dioxide is an addition to the risk management plan. Normal processing operations do not require on-site storage of sulfur dioxide gas. The Decatur facility normally operates a molten sulfur burner to create the sulfur dioxide for the process on an as needed basis (what is made is immediately used) but there are times when the sulfur burner must be taken out of

service for maintenance. During these limited maintenance periods a bulk tank truck will be utilized on-site as temporary storage. The tank truck storage capacity exceeds the sulfur dioxide threshold for inclusion in the Risk Management Program.

THE WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND THE ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIOS
To evaluate the worst case scenario and the alternate scenarios we have used the EPA's RMP Guidance for Off-Site Consequences analysis and EPA's RMPComp*. The following paragraphs provide details of the chosen scenarios.

THE GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 38 of the EPA. This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA-30 standard, NFPA-36 standard, applicable ANSI and ASME standards, and considering chemical supplier recommendations. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary facility.

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION
Tate & Lyle-Decatur maintains a record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment design associated with all processes.

PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS
Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The methodology used to carry out these analyses is the What If Scenarios. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering maintenance, and process operations that are revalidated at regular intervals. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. The most recent PHA review for the entire ethylene oxide storage tank/rail car unloading system was completed on 10/11/2007. The most recent PHA review for the sulfur dioxide system was completed on 11/15/2007.

OPERATIN

G PROCEDURES
For the purpose of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, Tate & Lyle-Decatur maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial start-up, normal operation, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a maintenance shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

TRAINING
Tate & Lyle-Decatur has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. Refresher training is provided as needed.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY
Tate & Lyle-Decatur carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to insure proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks includes: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Qualified personnel carry out maintenance operations with previous training in maintenance procedures. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE
Written procedures are in place at Tate & Lyle-Decatur to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. The most recent review/revision of maintenance procedures was completed on 10/11/07 for ethylene oxide and 11/15/07 for sulfur dioxide. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job task are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

PRE-START UP REVIEW
Pre-start up safety reviews relate to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted at regular practice at Tate & Lyle-Decatur. These reviews are conducted to c

onfirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe start-up prior to placing equipment in operation.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS
Tate & Lyle-Decatur receives corporate audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and RMP rule are being implemented. The most recent compliance audit was conducted EPA on August 6 - 7, 2007. Audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audit are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
Tate & Lyle-Decatur promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reocurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION
Tate & Lyle-Decatur truly believes that process safety management and incident prevention is a team effort. Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analysis.

CONTRACTORS
Our company hires contractors to conduct specialized and routine maintenance and construction activities. Long term relationships have been established with the contractors that work on a routine basis. All contract personnel are required to have the Decatur site specific training. The contractor training must be documented before a contract worker is allowed on the job site. The contractor safety representative meets with the Tate & Lyle-Decatur safety representative regularly. The contractor notifies Tate & Lyle-Decatur about any incident that results

in a near miss, accident, property damage, or injury of contract personnel. Tate & Lyle-Decatur keeps copies of the entire meeting notes and incident investigation reports to document past safety performance. Tate & Lyle-Decatur has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Tate & Lyle-Decatur has had no accidental releases that have adversely affected employees, public receptors, or plant property. During the period.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN
Tate & Lyle-Decatur has a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.

To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require modified emergency response.

The Macon County Emergency Planning Committee is the Local Emergency Planning Committee with which our emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.
